review_title: Internal hiring process makes Stalin look reasonable.
pros: If you're looking to get hired easily and put a big company on your resume, look no further. They will pay for your school and even some professional certifications, no tenure required.
cons:
Don't expect much of any opportunity to handle larger responsibilities on a relatively short-term basis. In most places being able to showcase your talent will open doors for you and improve your CV when you look at advancing your career, but with PayPal you'll just get discouraged when you're slapped in the face with the fact that you need to spend another year or two on the incremental raise treadmill before you're given consideration. If you're looking for a quick resume booster, it's great. If you're looking to build a career, look elsewhere.

Pay is substandard for most fields not handling calls. If you have 5 years to give and aren't concerned about the low pay, it's great - you can have PayPal reimburse a good chunk of your schooling and maybe a professional certification or two, then get your sabbatical (4 weeks paid leave, granted every 5 years of service) and jump ship. By the time you've been here for 5 years you've got enough experience to easily make 50% higher salary elsewhere. The lack of competitive pay is something brought up regularly in internal surveys but management insists the comprehensive picture is better, as though they expect anyone to believe a month of paid leave makes up for salary $20k/year below competitors.

review_title: Best Company I've ever worked for
pros:
Training is great, small classes with instructors who listen and understand concerns.
The system isn't perfect but is always improving, which is all that matters for a company.
Great benefits and things to do while on break, follow the rules and it's like being on vacation at work.
cons:
Some departments need better management to keep people sane.

When I was working there we were judged on how the customer rated us.
Who is going to give you a good rating if you work in the "limitations" department and the only customers you get are already irate about their account being locked (most of the time we weren't even able to remove the lock because other departments were way behind schedule). So we had Irate customers with no means of helping them because another department wasn't able to handle their work load. We were judged on the customer reviews that were out of our control.

A customer is given a survey about how you handled their call, it does not matter how polite and sincere you are, people are going to give you a bad rating when you are unable to resolve the issue with the result they wanted (due to PayPal's system). You can coat bad news with anything you want, they are still going to be angry their account is locked and give bad ratings.

PayPal created this no win situation by not paying attention to what happens when another department is reliant on another department.

pros: Most people are friendly, good work-life balance, some teams have decent work. If you love booze, you can party!
cons:
1) I can see politics and favouritism everywhere. There are only 2 kinds of people here: 'workers' and 'talkers'. People who do the hard work are literally treated like throw-away tissue-papers. But people who do all the talking are considered rockstars. I know people who do absolutely nothing, talk to the 'workers' in the team and when it comes to meetings, talk about the work that the 'workers' do and eventually they get promoted. The 'workers' have to fight really-hard for their career growth. If you are a quality engineer and know a little bit about the end-to-end of the product you are testing and if you have great communication skills, then PayPal is the place to be in. Forget about testing, you don't have to do that. The 'workers' will take the blame in case something breaks, but you can have a ball here, with people showering praises for the work that you weren't even involved in.

2) As a direct result of the favouritism shown to a selected set of people, they start to think they are God-level. So they start to become arrogant. I have seen mails and code reviews exchanged with sparks of arrogance thrown in (even if they don't know what the heck they are talking about). This creates conflict and in result, the good workers start leaving the company.

I was in that department for a few months, and the supervisor didnt like me so she made up about 15 different things to get me written up. She had no proof but I had no recourse. Went to HR, who did nothing. Because I was a simple agent and the other party was a supervisor, I had no ground to stand on. Nevermind that the year I spent in CS, I exceeded all company expectations and the supervisor stepped down to an agent position. Do not work for this company unless you like to be disrespected and back stabbed on a daily basis. Several of my friends who encouraged me to work there stated they loved it. I'm sure they used to be an awesome company, but  I think they are trying to keep up with competitors and keep their bank accounts in the 7 digits. Top down management style (explained below)

What the new senior management has been doing as part of a drive to redesign the company is to eliminate certain units, redesign some and grow a chosen few. The method of implementation however has not been to layoff employees, but it has been to create a very hostile work environment in specific groups and departments to encourage attrition. And in some cases where individuals do not leave in a few months - as a last resort, some employees get specifically targeted at each level where in a situation would be created for them that pushes them to leave. They would find themselves in a situation where a new construct requires a different skill set. Or their existing jobs may suddenly require them to work in a different location owing to a new drive in which every member of a single functional unit is to be sitting in the same office. Hence they would either end up in a situation in which they may be fired by finding some excuses for poor performance, or they get fed up and leave on their own if they act first.

What is also unfortunate is in such a environment, nepotism, racism and favoritism tends be very rampant as everyone tries to save their own skin

pros: The company ordinarily compensates their employees well (including granting a 4 week sabbatical after 5 years of service), and the vast majority of people I worked with were awesome! There's also a significant degree of diversity in the lower echelons and more than a few career opportunities (if you're in San Jose).
cons: Work/life balance can get seriously out of whack - there were weeks I worked 80 hours to get a project done and the only reward for going above and beyond was a "thanks" from my direct supervisor. You also have to constantly watch everything you say and do - even the things you think are innocent, like telling people other companies are hiring - there are people who will calmly throw you under the bus if it benefits them (but this is true everywhere). Diversity isn't nearly as pronounced at higher levels and career opportunities outside of San Jose are pretty minimal. Also, there is a significant loss of knowledge capital after people have taken their sabbatical.

cons: Unlike many internet companies PayPal is driven by a precise business model (payments) as opposed to technology. This has led to the company's success in becoming the dominant online payment system. The downside to this is that much of the technical decisions and execution were done in haste in order to bring features to market quickly. Also, the nature of payments requires a high degree of coupling between the various components. Because of this the code and systems put in place sometimes makes it a difficult environment to work in.

review_title: Being Underpaid is the main reason for all people leaving this company
pros: Benefits, stock options, great coworkers that are very down to earth. Somewhat flexible scheduling.
cons: It's turned into a corporate monster. Its all about politics and private relationships when it comes to advancement past 15$p/h. To the point where a "fake it to make it" mentality is actually suggested by people in higher positions. Ineffective management system for this changing company. Long time employees not being fairly comps stars for increased responsibilities while new hires with minimal responsibilities and liabilities are hire in at 9 to 10 ratio of current compensation. To maintain momentum in advancement thru the company you must become a corporate lackey, potentially compromising your beliefs and morals for advancement. It all feels very robotic and cold yet overall communication is terrible,  at even a team leader level(supervisor). Often leaving employees learning from customers. The most common reason for employees leaving paypal is because the responsibilities given are not fairly compensated.

review_title: Cold and corporate, has lost its humanity
pros: Good health care benefits,  extended bonding/leave time for new parents,
cons: I worked there 13 years and saw a lot of changes over the years, mostly good but ever since they separated from eBay in 2015, it's really gone downhill fast. They have forced good agents into roles they do not want to do and anymore it's about making and saving money, they hammer productivity into our heads on a daily basis and don't get me started on the horrible micromanagement! They treat you like an elementary school kid who needs a hall pass to use the bathroom when you get up from your desk for 30 seconds to go get a drink. Plus they got rid of a lot of the cool and fun incentive and recognition programs for employees.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros: The compensation was not bad (if you don't compare it with Tier I companies like Google, FB. LinkedIn, etc.). The facility is nice (if you don't mind open space). You can find there some nice and smart people.
cons:
Depending on your luck you may or may not have a reasonable manager. I was not that lucky. 
The infrastructure is simply a joke. A lot of time spent figuring out why something that is supposed to work is not working.
The processes which you'd expect to find in the mature company are almost entirely absent. 
As a result the code quality is in a pretty sad state. The Live issues are pretty common and surrounded with a lot of drama.
The technology stack is ancient. (Although it depends on the group you will be part of). 
The work force diversity is lacking (and sometimes missing entirely).
Your experience at Paypal depends on which group you join but overall I'd say that the chances are not that good.

review_title: great place to work with the culture and all
pros: diversity, inclusion, collaboration, great benefits (every one says so...personally, mever had a job with benefits so i dont have a benchmark) and very accomodating when life throws you a curve ball... what more could you want?
cons: new attendance policy for 2017 is EXTREMELY draconian.  used to be 90 day roll-off for missed days now they hang on for an entire year and after 3 it's a weite up.  can be understood if it started clean on Jan 1 2017, but they pulled a 90 day lookback for the last quarter of 2016 so anyone with missed days rolling off normally now have to carry those throughout 2017

job_title: Member of Technical Staff I Software Engineer in Austin, TX
pros: Diversity is great and as the payments landscape is evolving very fast a lot of opportunities are available. As an engineer you can drive change that will take the company to next ride ; management is pretty open to hear about that and fund it.
cons: As of today, if you expect leadership to drive changes, then this might not be the place for you. As company had and is going through many core team changes and focuses. i feel its loosing focus on next action plan or idea of change on payments landscape now. Things might change when it becomes a full time payments company.

pros:
* You get a lot of Extra activities to participate.
* Good employee benefits like Stocks
* Some really good techies
cons:
* Your team matters. I'm a full-stack developer with java background. But I was made to work in C++ code and they allocated QE Task and automation for a few months.
* I really hate the way AWF's(Alternative WorkForce) are treated here. I'm an FTE ( Full Time Employee) and any team outings including company-sponsored team lunch AWF was avoided. Director will behave like as if they don't exist
* PayPal should get rid of this Hire and Fire culture. You will get to see a developer with some technology stack getting fired and they will recruit a new guy with the same technology stack
* People don't get noted for the work they do. They get noted only for the marketing they do.
* You can see many people who blame others for the failures.
* Again the team matters, in the team I work there is no proper road map, senior architects fight among themselves to decide things.No one works for one good product here. Everyone wants to do something to keep them alive

pros: Excellent benefits and work/life balance. 10 paid holidays, lots of time off and they now offer sick time which is new. Great benefits for new parents. Depending on the location there is opportunity for growth. Progressive minded company. There is a lot of potential for growth for PayPal. Good entry level compensation.
cons: Your mileage may vary here. PayPal is generally behind when it comes to innovation in the payments space. If feels like we are always a step behind and when a product is launched it lacks key features. Constant micro management and lack of competent leadership in the middle of the organization is chasing out the talent. Compensation does not scale with experience and most people find out they are worth more on the external job market and leave. The culture and values are great, just not really embraced by mid level leadership.

pros:
1. Flexibility in work, ( You can take work from home, But if u want continuous days for WFH, you should get managers approval)
2. There is no dresscode ( You can even come in shorts and round neck t-shirts)
3. Highly configured devices are given for working (laptops, if u support any application u will be given samsung s9 phone)
4. Food at the Food court is maintained well in terms of quality, Afternoon meals is not good.
5. Transport is provided for all employees even for the contractors, In fact buses are the best i have traveled so far. 
5. Compensation is above par compared to 90% of CMMI level5 companies.
6. If you work hard, you will be rewarded, if you are struggling/taking much time in doing the work, they don't even respect you.
7. Free snacks and cool drinks are available entire day mostly.
cons:
1. They don't help you, you should get the things for you. You should be ready to work in any technology. 
2. The managers expectations are huge
3. Most of the freshers they recruit from popular colleges like (Bits pilani, VIT, NITs), So managers compare you with them.

review_title: Good company to work for overall but a struggle for top performers who expect faster paced change and job acceleration
job_title: Strategy and Business Development in London, England
pros:
- nice culture
- good benefits
- ample vacation time (London based employee)
- strong family values
- open door to management
- opportunity to distinguish yourself and make an impact if you're willing to work hard, drive change and produce creative solutions to problems
cons:
- not great at promoting top performers (they seem to subject everyone to the same 2 year promotion process regardless of how good they are). 
- legacy of A* performers leaving because change is too slow / frustrating. in turn C players tend to stick around and get promoted by default.
- siloed environment - not a lot of true cross functional collaboration
- marketing is only just becoming more consumer oriented. professionals tend to be uncreative and unhelpful and supporting anything outside of their core agenda. 
- product has to do SJ's bidding. very little regional control or resource to support new ideas that might move the needle.
- slow to get anything done

pros:
Transportation from San Francisco (charter bus)
Smart and motivated people who care about one another
Onsite gym / extensive cafe options
If you are a high performer you will be well paid / advance
Bagel Wednesday, daily fruit/ snacks
cons:
Too big to call themselves a start up - but they call themselves a 'big startup' and use that to a fault
Depending on the organization there is little to no support of work-life-balance
Whatever organization has the budget makes all the decisions - usually at the impact of the customer.
Schizophrenic culture - in the 6+years I was there I experience an org change or massive roadmap impacting project (which would take all resources) every single year. 
Agreements made in the conference room are not always kept

review_title: Good benefits; good working environment; difficult development environment.
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Work life balance is quite good. Flex time is available as is working from home in some situations. Benefits are excellent. Good people to work with - smart and helpful. Regular team lunches and outings are provided. Lower management is receptive to criticism and supportive. Infrequent demands for more than 40 hours per week.
cons: Development environment is archaic. Infrastructure is fragile. Code base is immense, poorly documented, and poorly understood. Too much emphasis is given to new features over consolidating and solidifying existing features. Middle and upper management are focused too much on marketing requests at the expense of development needs. Emphasis is placed on development days rather than productivity. Development tools are outdated. Available information is disorganized and not maintained. Developer productivity suffers greatly due to poor code organization, old tools, enormous code base, unstable development environment, and questionable management decisions. Stock price has been flat for the last four years.

review_title: This is a call centre, pretended to be a tech company.
pros: Free coffee. Heath insurance. Sabbatical 25 days extra holidays. Free gym (poorly equipped though)
cons:
Long training. Instead of teaching their PDA tools, they engage you in unrelated learning and activities.
They tell you  that salary is 25 k per year but in fact it's paid every 4 weeks which equals  25 k per 13 months instead. The new bonus system presumes your statistics must be 100% otherwise no bonus.
Two clocking system one for your salary another for your stats. 
If you want to go to toilet you have to click on a button and the time you spend there is added to your statistics. Any mistakes made when working on a case added to your statistics. 
No opportunities for verical growth but  if your statistics are right you can go to other department. 
10 hours shifts and only 30, 15 and 15 min breaks. 30 min isn’t paid and you stuck there for 10.5 hours instead.
For PayPal you just a numeric piece of statistic.

review_title: A great company to work for...if you put in the time
pros: PayPal is the undisputed leader in online payments and things are constantly changing. As a company that's been established for nearly twenty years, it's still operates as a start-up at heart but suffers from growing pains in various fields. This leads to new opportunities for those who are willing to step out of their comfort zones. For those that want a stable job and don't care too much for new roles, they will fit in as well. There are many lifers working for PayPal in their operation centers. The company is employee focused and is constantly updating their benefits packages to stay at the leading edge for offerings. The company has some flexibility with scheduling which allows for a healthy work/life balance.
cons: Promotional opportunities are based on your past performance ratings, so if you've had a supervisor who rated you unfairly you'll find it difficult to promote. The pay is competitive at the entry levels, but as you promote they lose some of the competitive edge.

review_title: A lot of politics used to run IDC, now things are changing in a good way
pros: Cool work culture, flexible timings, WFH options, a LOT of extra benefits
cons: If unlucky then may get stuck in some politics. Location is chennai which becomes a BIG factor in good people moving out of the company(bangalore has started just now)

review_title: Rants and frustrations of an an honest man
pros: None None None None None
cons: Absolute waste of time. Hopeless management who treat people like third class citizens. The class divide is too much between the staff and the management. The top brass think they are blue blooded(literally). This is all about the Chennai team (am not aware of the culture at other locations, but i don't think it will be any different). They do Agile and that's all they care about. Endless hours of lying and pleasing the Rally tool, so that management can fool off its top brass to earn good bonuses and profits. PayPal Chennai is what everything that's wrong about modern India. Brash, uncultured, and utterly pointless. Wish I could rant more, but what's going to change? Nothing probably. I would give no rating if I could, but again forced by the idiocy of the web developer to award PayPal a generous one start from me. I don't want people slating me, it's not my fault if you have low standards. I have worked previously in quality companies where people with double Phd's walk with humility that would shame you to death. Probably everything that's said about PayPal applies to every other company here. That's the only saving grace for the disaster that is PayPal Chennai.

review_title: Liked the company/mission, hard to avoid the department politics.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros:
Decent pay 
Employee relief fund for hardship
Ability to work from home in most departments
Month sabbatical offered after every 5 years of employment
cons:
Meeting culture is a productivity killer, “let’s have meetings just to have them”. And if you decline a meeting, expect to have a follow-up meeting scheduled to discuss why. 

If you don’t care to advance your career, this is a good place for you. Even if you have a supportive manager advocating for you, unless your department has a competent HR business partner and not just a roadblock, you can bet HR will either 1) shut the promotion recommendation down immediately 2) attempt to understand the employee’s job function and promotion justification with repeated inquiries for the same information, creating churn and additional work to deter managers from pursuing this process.  Of course there are exceptions - if you’re a savvy politician, you have a chance of being promoted. It was demoralizing to work efficiently “do more with less”, see other people coasting and being rewarded for it.

review_title: Good Benefits, More Indians, Micro Mgmt in all Scrums
pros:
- Great Benefits
- Great CEO (Dan Schulman) and CTO (Bill Ready)
- Encouraging physical environment
- Uses the best technology tools
- Non-senior developers are the best (Don't go to seniors for questions, they have attitude)
cons:
- Micro Management
 - Standups are more than 30 mins, goes to an hour or so
- No Multi-culture
- Higher or executive management don't care under the hood when employees are stressing out with micromanagement of these bad managers.
- Code added complexity by senior guys, they only know... and they are busy... on top of it, they show off that they are best brains when you go to them. The first thing to eradicate/reduce, the manager should stop going to them for everything.

pros:
Growing environment for fresh grads
Freedom of work life
Opportunity to vocate your ideas
cons:
They quote a made up CTC which would be twice your base salary and you wont know how they arrived at that amount, as end of the year what you get is much less.

If you have a joining bonus component be very careful. They will take it back based on the service period condition on your offer letter. But never mention the amount they have taken back on any paper, not even From 16. Payroll team is extremely rude and harsh. They will not tell you till your last day how much money you have to pay back. And you have to pay then and there by cheque. 

Now, you keep mailing HR, they would not mention about this amount in your From 16 and you end up paying a huge tax amount (1/3 rd of the bonus). Nobody from HR, your director, manager would understand your argument and ask the payroll to correct the From 16. Complete harassment I would say.

review_title: Not a good place to work
pros: They offer insurance and 401K as almost any other job does.
cons: They do not promote from within.  Management decides when and who to enforce policy on and does not look out for the company but looks out for their own jobs and eliminates those who they feel may be a potential risk to their own employment. Promotions and advancement are not given based on job performance but on who plays the "game" well.  There is no work/life balance, nor equal compensation, no sick leave and the lower level employees have no schedule flexibility.

pros: I have been with PayPal almost two years now and I still look forward to coming in to work each week.  My contributions have been valued from the start and my efforts have been rewarded. We have excellent benefits including vacation, 401k match, stock purchases, and bonuses.  Most of all I love the flexibility I have been afforded with my work schedule; it has allowed me to volunteer at my children's schools and ensure I'm able to provide for their needs as a mother. Lastly, there is a very active women's affinity network and I've had the opportunity to work with some great leaders as shadows and mentors.
cons: PP is a fast paced company in an industry that is changing; this means there is a lot of change and requires flexibility on our part as employees.  I love this and thrive in an environment such as this that never gets stale, but some may find the change difficult to adapt to.

review_title: A good company to work for IF you can secure the right position.
job_title: Sales Development Representative in Omaha, NE
pros: Benefits are probably the best of any company that I've ever heard of and I'm not just speaking of health benefits and stock options. PayPal offers everything from tuition reimbursement to a free membership with Care.com.
cons: If you want a position outside of customer service, you must be prepared to work your behind off and deal with the politics of a large corporate world. And trust me, unless you're a college kid working towards a degree, you WANT to be out of customer service. In the position that I was in, I was one of five in the entire company supporting three rather large departments. I loved my job, but there was SO much drama and cattiness. People have been in these positions so long, it was like High School all over again.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros:
If you are an employee without a product, there is a large amount of freedom. (However, most people are not.)
The pay is reasonably good, and there is a very large acceptance of gigs on the side. This is a good place to put in the minimum workload, get a salary, and build your own startup. There is a fair number of frustrated employees who do exactly that, making PayPal an excellent place to put together a startup team.
cons:
PayPal has a tradition of documenting code poorly, and of performing reorgs every 3 years. This combination makes it almost impossible to change any code: you probably cannot find anybody who knows what the code does. If you find that person -- or if you are a person who knows what the code does -- then the process of getting approval to make a change is tedious, and again, frustrated by occasional reorgs. 

People working in Austin or Scottsdale are often more frustrated than those in San Jose.

job_title: New Member Agent in Chandler, AZ
pros: They have good people who work there and they have decent benefits.
cons: Outrageous metrics. I worked there for 2 years and they do nothing but make your job harder. To give an example, they changed the entire layout of the customer profiles without notifying their agents. When we got customers calling in asking us about the new look we sounded stupid, we had to help customers the best we could and that took more time than usual. then they had the nerve to criticize us for having a longer handle time. That is just ONE example. They shove it down your throat about what a great company they are and how you should feel lucky to work there. Don't be fooled, they do not care about you even when they say they do. They're full of it. Nothing but bad management. I no longer work there and my stress levels aren't nearly as bad as they were when I worked there. Job seekers be warned.

job_title: Senior Manager, Product Marketing in San Jose, CA
pros:
1. The People - many bright, talented, fun, interesting people throughout the company, and it's generally a pleasure to work with them.
2. Education - PayPal is a complicated business with a lot of moving parts. I've learned more in my time there than in any previous job.
3. Innovation - PayPal does push the envelope with clever new business models and technology, and in that sense it's a lot of fun.
4. Success - The business is doing very very well, growing quickly with strong margins. It's fun to be part of a winning team and feel like you contributed to the company's success.
cons:
1. The changing culture - As PayPal grows larger, the style of leadership just isn't as open or collaborative as it used to be. It's become much more hierarchical.
2. Lack of focus - PayPal is trying to go too many directions at once instead of focusing on doing a few things right.
3. Focus on quality - PayPal doesn't invest enough in the quality of their systems and processes and it often shows up as a bad customer experience.

pros: 27 days paid leaves, no dress code, cab facility and free packaged fruit juice and banana in a day n also some nuts.
cons:
One will always have a pressure to perform, as quality 80%, AHT  and Action rate has to be maintained throughout. And the initial mistakes done while learning might impact your YTD performance and if you take any unplanned leave , a mail with all the points will be in your inbox... You will be kept in PIP for 30 days and if still u don't perform till 80% then u r out.
Every company needs benchmark to measure performance and to set a target..But this company sets unrealistic targets and keeps employees under pressure. Although we get 1.5 hr break each day, but for rest 7.5 hours ,cases keep on coming back to back with AHT in seconds and one needs to think even before going to wash room... I will never recommend anyone here.

job_title: Enterprise Sales and Strategy in Toronto, ON
pros: Very good people across the org, who had a strong sense of urgency. PayPal brings real value to brands, and the results are there.  Only downside in sales at that time was a bit of a good ole boys club whereby certain employees were set up with preferential lists and deals/money to make them work. Sure that has changed.
cons: Company has changed in terms of culture. Not nearly as disruptive or hungry. More yes people who are rewarded for never sticking their neck out. Some people have been there for years with little to no performance to speak of. That tends to happens at a certain size.  Dan seems like a good guy with the right values, which is important in any leadership scenario.

review_title: PayPal has a good work environment and they take care of their employees.
pros: Progressive benefits, lots of P.T.O., good health, dentist, and life insurance available. There is opportunity for lateral changes periodically, if you want to try a new position. There is also opportunity to progress upward. The work environment overall is good. They also offer school tuition reimbursement.The management was nice and did everything that they could to set you up for success. They allow you to plan for your progression and set goals to get where you want to be in the company.
cons: Most positions at PayPal require receiving and/or calling customers. Call center jobs are stressful in general. Depending on your department the benefits are based on surveys from customers, which are inconsistent and hard to control. For example you could please 9/10 customers but only 2/10 get a survey and one of those could be the unpleased customer. They are also based on call handle time which means that you are always in a hurry to close the call.

review_title: Good Training ground for Payments / Technology for employees from Financial services
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros:
Paypal is one of the few technology companies where employees from financial institutions can join at a lateral level or even a role with higher seniority than the one they held at a financial institution. 

It is a recognized name in Silicon Valley and can be a great training ground in product management, technology, payments and user experiences

While it has all the issues associated with working for a large company, one is recognized for hard work, creativity and desire to collaborate across teams.
cons:
1) Not considered to be one of the "hot" valley companies and is not in the same league as Google / Apple / Facebook

2) Future a bit unsure after split from Ebay

3) It feels like Paypal is resting on its past laurels and glory versus building a product for the future

review_title: good for a start, then move on!
pros: If you are interested in online banking / commerce / fraud, you will learn much in Paypal. Salaries, a much debated point, could be higher, but could be worse too. Benefits are, I think, decent. Good work / life balance. 25 days off per year isn't bad either.
cons: Hard,  and sometimes meaningless, targets. Promotions can be hard to get. Work,  in some positions,  can be very repetitive, thus boring, and very probably quite unhealthy both for the mind and the body.  Little autonomy in some roles, and are you treated like an adult, really?  Everything  feels like  in constant turmoil. In spite of these obvious pitfalls, you are forever told that Paypal is the best thing since the invention of sliced bread. Given all of this, attrition rate is high enough.  My advice: learn from Paypal and move on to a different company where you will get more money and more respect.

pros: I loved the people on my from start to finish. I found coaches who were willing to develop me, and I stuck by them. I was bummed to leave PayPal for the relationships I had built and the skills I had gained from my mentors
cons:
So much of employee engagement, happiness, and consistency depended on what team you were on. As an agent who began on the phones, I and others were constantly switched from team lead to team lead. Some were better than others, and a few were down right awful. There was very little consistency and as I moved up in my career, that didn't change. 

As a facilitator I felt much more apart of my team, but many trainers were overworked, didn't know their schedules most of the time until last minute, and didn't have any effective facilitation guidelines to be held accountable for. Everyone trained in their own style.

pros:
* Swell company once. Built great products, the focus was on building products. Once is the keyword
* Really smart co-workers
* Once, you could either go full corporate or startup if you can make it here
cons:
* Not building products anymore, just cruising on earlier steam - if you count out some VPs pet projects which'll never make production
* Now focussing way too much on people. Not in a good way. Like you have to "evangelize" certain tech to survive. You gotta drink that kool-aid all the way down to make it. They are not even hiding it - look at the job descriptions. With that come all the bad things: politics, groupism..
* Now, if you are here, you either can't make it to the top-tier or you made a wrong choice in choosing a "secure" job
* Middle management is hopelessly entrenched - no matter who's at the top, they are very good at generating smoke and wind. Lower order is over-worked, messed with on a regular basis for no reason.
* Stack ranking and idiotic metrics will measure your performance.

review_title: Good Company for Freshers and not for experienced
pros: You get pampered with things like things to eat and drink at cafeteria, Wifi buses, nice work desk, game room and many events.
cons:
No good hikes
Getting promotion might takes more than 5 years for mid and seniors. Only for freshers, promotion happens in a year and that too just 1 promotion.
Most of the team have untalented Managers except a few good ones from development. All other vertical managers like engineering, IT, QA, DW etc are worst.

review_title: good experience would do it again
job_title: Principal Software Engineer in Austin, TX
pros:
For Austin the stock compensation is best in class ( RSU's and ESPP).
Benefits were good, PTO, and sabbatical, decent 401k, decent medical.
Nice office space with walking path, gym, lots of windows for light.
at the end PayPal was a great place to explore new technology and take it from idea into production.
Very solid support teams ( dev ops etc...).
There were a few tough and long nights dealing with releases or produciton issues, but the process improved to where releasing code was always smooth and quick.
Very thorough pre-testing of production releases.
cons: The biggest con was being in Austin.  The original CEO was Scott Thompson who supported and championed the site.  After 3 CEO changes there is no senior management at the Austin site and for the most part everything is controlled out of San Jose.  I don't think the site will last much longer as the interest in Austin seems to be waning.

pros: I really enjoying working as a limitation agent has it up and downs more ups than downs which is great, I find with having two team leaders since I started was great as both of them are down to earth and good for giving me direction. I think PayPal is a great company to work for and would suggest it to anyone looking for a job.
cons: I think one of my biggest cons would be around public holidays as I find it unfair that we have to be in on public holidays as there is very limited PTO which is understandable but wouldn't mind Woking Irish bank holidays if we got the US ones off so maybe that could be changed and for a hot food to be served from 4:45 to 7 regardless of if canteen will lose money from it.

job_title: Customer Solutions Specialist in Omaha, NE
pros: Great benefits package, decent starting wage
cons: Paypal is a great place to work if you want to be stuck in single position for years with little wage increase. Change happens very quickly at PayPal, although not in a good way. You are constantly shoveled from team to team (within same department of course) and have a new team leader every 3-4 months, which you have to explain your career goals to every time and right when you think you're going to get somewhere BAM. New team. New boss. No actual advancement. The initial training received was completely inadequate. When you actually start your job you are incredibly overwhelmed. Also, the attendance policy changes are impossible. Flawed incentive system makes it very difficult to get a sizeable bonus or any bonus at all. The internal talent search is a joke.

job_title: Software Development Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: High growth business that could do great things.  PayPal can do a lot and can be a market leader.  The potential is there.  The payments opportunities for PayPal are really huge and still relatively untapped.  The compensation packages are pretty good.  The management wants to do right by its people.
cons: They don't care about doing good engineering.  We have a bloated engineering organization that hires warm bodies.  There is no focus on creating a solid product.  Everything is turf war and political with the most decisions being based on what extend empires not what is the right thing to do.

pros: A giant in payment industry, works at very very large scale. Lots of opportunity for career if you land into right org and team to work on some really learning oriented and challenging software problems. Work life balance if great. Fairly compensating using fixed portion but through RSU/Incentives it goes very good.
cons: Changing team is not easy if you do not have personal connect. Not so open to use any technology that a developer wants but they are limiting to approved tech stacks only. They also work a lot on custom stacks.

pros:
Review specific to data services in paypal chennai
# Few good managers and leads, they have challenging assignments in latest technology and great visibility, team name - visualization, enterprise
# Free snacks, free transport, free wifi, free gym, free badminton court, basketball court, Independent contributor

# Many sessions on latest technologies and domain knowledge shared
cons:

# Expect to support on all leaves, weekend, holidays in case of an Issue no matter if it is priority 0 or priority infinite.

review_title: So much opportunity, so little execution
job_title: Group Product Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: PayPal has a unique opportunity to become the world's favorite way to pay and be paid. It can enter into any financial service, it can offer all sorts of payment products and enhancements, like offers, discounts, loyalty, big data. Past management has dragged their feet, but new leaders promise a start-up and experimental approach that bodes well.
cons: PayPal has terrible hiring and people management practices, which results in lousy managers hiring huge numbers of lousy people. There exist massive departments filled with friends of friends, most of whom do little work. Years of poor management means that these departments grow regularly every year. There is very little path to promotion from within, because leadership does not seek to groom talent, but hires director-and-up positions from outside.

review_title: Fast maturing company with cohesive leadership (even while new president is being recruited) and excited rank and file
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros:

review_title: Too many politics! Too much upper management! Horrible review and promotion process!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros: Good pay. Lots of good people.
cons:
The review process is not objective, there is no way you can defend your performance because it is not based on objective, measurable,pass/fail criteria. 

In other places I've worked at, you set measurable objective goals at the beginning of the period. At the end of the period you can say with confidence you met or not met your goals or perhaps exceeded your goals, and you are evaluated accordingly. It makes sense!

At PayPal you get "compared" to other employees in your organization. And when you ask your manager to explain why you got the rating you got, it is never an objective, measurable, pass/fail goals.

It is a well known "secret" that managers are forced to evaluate their team based on a bell curve, so even if you have a lot of superstars on your team, the manager is going to have to single one or a couple out to be given a "sub par" evaluation.

Some of the people that do not deliver anything, or that have their projects get promoted. While others that do deliver a working project, on time, get fired... go figure.

review_title: Good but stagnant and individuals ruin everything
pros:
- Diverse working environment.
- Casual dress code.
- Transportation and shift allowances provided.
- Fair wage considering the hours and work-life balance.
- Ability to buy PayPal stocks at an employee discount.
- Free/subsidized snacks and drinks from the vending machines.
- Occasional parties with food and gifts for any cultural celebration.

cons:
- Upward mobility is stagnant.
- Employees being shuffled from department to department on the pretext of "upskill" with no change in salary grade and no additional wage.
- For executive-level hiring process, the company dismisses previous work experiences that are not in banking/financial services.
- Many overqualified employees for the positions they're holding.
- Despite the many D & I initiatives, the company can't stop individual employees from being racist/sexist and those who act inappropriately but not outright abusive often go unpunished. There's too much babying of bullies who are treated as if they don't intentionally want to hurt others, and too much focus on victims to alter their own behavior when faced with bullies.

There is a great future ahead. Come join PayPal if you want to be part of something great!

This is part of the excitement as we get to create this new company's culture. There are growing pains, but these are to be expected and are fun to work through.

review_title: Great place, but it was a dead end.
pros: Fun, exciting place to work.  I learned a ton and got to work on some really cool projects.  The people are very smart.  Good pay. Top-notch benefits.
cons:
Very hard to get promoted.  eBay/PayPal uses the horrible "stack ranking" system (google it to learn more.)  Everybody I knew was very dedicated and working extremely hard, but the arbitrary rules for performance evaluation demanded that only a small percentage could be recognized/rewarded for excellence.  

Too many re-orgs, too much politics.
Most people were nice, but they were over-shadowed by a handful of abrasive types with big egos.
Your experience may be good or bad, depending on which org you're in.

pros: Cheap snacks.  Decent benefits.
cons:
Wayyy too many meetings and huddles and "this is the best company" propaganda.  They make a lot of noise to distract people from the low pay, crap hours, and the lack of job security.  You could perform your job exactly as you're supposed to, but if you get bad reviews by customers who are angry at company policies, you can and will be fired.  No job security.   I've seen way too many good employees fired - whose supervisors even said they handled their calls/emails exactly as they were supposed to but shrugged it off as "the numbers are what the higher-ups look at."

Doctor's notes do not excuse absences, so I have seen people fired after car wrecks, bouts with illnesses such as pneumonia, and even early childbirth.

I found another job and got out of there ASAP.

pros:

After that, all the employees are subject of a Big Brother experimentation, cameras everywhere, people that know exactly what you did or said or typed or bought, and most important, everything can be used against you by anyone with the title to do that. I don't know if all the multinational are doing that to control their employees (if yes, I don't wonna go to work for Google), but here in PP they do, and it is bad. job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros:
There seems to be a new culture and movement brought it by our new CEO Dan and his staff. There are a lot of exciting things happening and the company will have the opportunity to show what it can do on its own now that is has separated from eBay inc.

Competitive Pay, Great Benefits
cons:
Since the split, it seems a lot of organizations have lost their direction. A lot of the talent was split among the two companies and a lot of teams are trying to figure out where they are going now that some of their leaders are gone. I think eventually it will get settled. After all this is expected after a split, but it's the team members that decide to stay instead of jumping ship that are paying the price.

In my experience, career growth opportunities have been very limited.

The food is awful and expensive!

pros: Good commissions within sales and good bonus for account management. free lunch, discounted health care and gym memberships. Drinks on Friday.
cons:
Not enough girls! 
Clear favouritism from management/leadership team and unless you are their 'buddy' don't even think about getting a promotion. 
If you want any career progression at all it's all up to you. They do not update you on which teams are hiring. 
They don't promote from global opps to the business unit because there seems to be fierce competition and/or no communication between departments. 
Hardly any support from leadership and the sales team have lost 2 team leaders within 6 months because of the environment. 
Lots of constant changes within the team that disrupt the peace. 
The global opps team is very obviously tight on budget that they try to make as many cuts as possible.

pros: The company has a lot of resources and they have invested in good reporting tools.
cons:
Too much of gimmicks of looking into customer experience but nothing for real. 
Group leaders who have been around since the time they were hired would do almost anything for personal gains.  No proper guideline for work related matters and agents can always manipulate the system as there's no proper governance on processes.
There are times when you'd be afraid to report process gaps due to the politics and the labelling which take place.
Incompetent managers who are around just to get promoted by impressing their superiors by putting up shows. 
The company is basically running on autopilot mode as they have already have strong customer base due to the lack of competitors in the market.

review_title: Good if you want a job, terrible if you want a career
pros: 15 days PTO in year 1, medical insurance starts on day 1,  Sabbatical after 5 years, activities and events to keep young people engaged (prom themed Christmas party. They gave out yearbooks as gifts.)
cons: There is no room to do anything in your career. Everything is hourly and the average age has got to be just out of high school. They force you to have a development plan, but it is all for show as there is no where to go. This is a great place if you have a high school education or got a college degree in theater, but if you are a business professional, know that the job you take is the job you will have until you decide to leave.

review_title: A place where you can really have an impact if you're a passionate go-getter
job_title: Senior Manager, Global Functions in San Jose, CA
pros: I've been at PayPal just over a year now and seen it through some big changes in such a short time.  The executive team are really authentic and inspiring.  They are very open to change and new ideas from anywhere in the business. People are generally helpful and working toward the same vision for the company.  It's a really inspiring place to be right now.  You feel you are making a positive impact on the world and great opportunities for your career.
cons: Like any big company it has it's challenges of having to go through different processes and groups to get things done. But they are determined to make it easier. It's a complicated business and structure so sometimes hard to fully understand what everyone does.

review_title: could be so much better than it is
pros:
- free catered meals daily
- gorgeous work space
- weekly in-office happy hour
cons:
- stuffy environment
- culture is confusing ... there are tons of former finance leaders who transitioned over to tech when they came to PayPal, but have brought old practices and outdated values with them
- NO diversity
- egos and entitlement are a major issue ... people don't give you the time of day unless they consider you to be important enough or you have a "respectable" title
- constant org changes and managers who are looking out for themselves, not what's best for their teams

job_title: Group Product Manager in San Jose, CA
pros:
1) Compensation and great work life balance are the main reasons to work for PayPal. 

2) With a new board thanks to the work of an activist shareholder who also was also instrumental in shaking up earlier management and board there is a new ray of hope and accountability for the future.

3) Risk management is the only place where things are still happening.
cons:
1) More PMs than engineers. So if you are a PM your either cranking out ppts or making cases to get engineers.

2) Strategy is tops down (Snr. VPs and above). Everyone else is a worker bee trying to perform on an already defined roadmap.

3) You almost never directly present to leadership and they never talk to you. Like most traditional large corporations, you do the work and its presented by your manager or his/her manager.

4) Bottoms up innovation yields pats on the back and awards but is never funded to see the light of day.

5) Way more political to an extent that even leaders are afraid of making decisions

review_title: Way too political and no long term view or outlook.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros:
The work is great, demanding and exciting.
There is a long journey ahead and enough interesting things to learn and implement.
cons:
Way too political and at times hostile culture which is very negative. Everyone is expected to say positive things in larger meetings and take dissenting opinions outside of even planning meetings. 
After a while, senior engineers and even managers get disinterested in providing their feedback and just focus on the job required.

pros: It has a great business model, with a massive customer base, and by all accounts, it should grow into an absolutely enormous company (if it isn't already). There are no real competitors to speak of, and the area to grow into is enormous.
cons: As a software engineer, this place has gotten too big for me, and the technology hasn't scaled at all. There's constantly a desperate attempt to manage resources and to make sure no one breaks the site in any way (which is understandable) which means there's way too much process and overhead and not enough time to actually write some code and see how it works. Too many people have conflicting priorities.

review_title: Sites outside San Jose are second class workers
job_title: Senior QA Engineer in Scottsdale, AZ
pros:
Some learning opportunities
Good compensation
Great benefits if you work in San Jose.  Poor benefits elsewhere.
cons:
Dead end job unless you are from same region of India as your boss
Worst communication from management and between departments of any company I've seen in 30 years.

pros:
- Fixed timing with no expectation of working over time.
- If over time is required then employee is compensated accordingly even if the OT is only for 1 hour or less.
cons:
- Management is unprofessional and except employees to take everything that is dumped on them.
- Employees have to face the consequences even if the mistake is on team leader or manager's part.
- Favoritism is present in some teams. 
- Some times team leader likes to micro manage and questions every single thing.
- Expect to be chased around for achieving a better AHT. You could already be doing your best but its never enough for them.

pros: Great benefits and compensation packages
cons:
Impossible stats to keep
No discretion in how we handle accounts and phone calls
They made the stat structure almost impossible to meet just so they don't have to give out as many bonuses. 
PayPal was in the Top 10 best places to work in Omaha for a few years in a row. In 2011 they we not on the list.

job_title: Director of Marketing in San Jose, CA
pros: Great campus, good benefits, lots of opportunity as a business, and some good people trying to make a difference. But .....
cons: Poor, inexperienced and disorganized senior management and leadership, continuous re-organizations, lack of corporate alignment; plenty of self interested agenda's, and a culture of 'Me' versus 'Us.' A lot of leaders faking it. In terms of process, discipline and expertise in people and process, PayPal is very poor. Business is heavily dependent on eBay customer base. Buy or sell stock? Sell!

review_title: A great place to work with a few minor blips that are common to all large corporations.
pros:
1. Upward Feedback - you get to anonymously rate your immediate supervisor
2. They really mean it when they tell you there are advancement opportunities - almost everyone in our department was promoted to their position from within the company
3. Benefits start the first day of employment - no 90-day waiting period that is so common for the industry
cons: 1. Layers of management / approvals can make it hard to accomplish anything - we know how to do our jobs, now just get your noses out of Operations and let us mitigate risk!

review_title: A great place to work with a few minor blips that are common to all large corporations.

2. They really mean it when they tell you there are advancement opportunities - almost everyone in our department was promoted to their position from within the company
3. Benefits start the first day of employment - no 90-day waiting period that is so common for the industry
cons: 1. Layers of management / approvals can make it hard to accomplish anything - we know how to do our jobs, now just get your noses out of Operations and let us mitigate risk!

review_title: A well equipped ship that completely depends on how you steer it.
pros:
1. It depends mostly on teams. I'm lucky to find a nice team and manager who is very supportive and always gives me tons of opportunities to explore. Enough freedom to play around with things that are new to me.
2. The mixed crowd and the cosmopolitan culture. You don't feel like you've landed up in Mars. Big up to Bangalore for that.
cons:
Mix of good and bad apples in every team but that is common everywhere I guess. More Hackathons to inspire the culture of innovation (Not that they don't happen but should happen more frequently). More interaction between different teams[I don't know many of the folks in office :( ].
Need a gym in the Bangalore office.

pros: There is a saying, ' IF YOU WANT TO LIFT YOURSELF UP, LIFT UP SOMEONE ELSE'. Proud to say that PayPal actually gives me an opportunity to develop my subordinates, which eventually develops my skills as a leader. We live by the rule of Servant Based Leadership whereby while we help facilitate development for our subordinates, our leaders help to facilitate and support our development to go to the next level of leadership. We dedicate one on ones with the teammates and commit to it, which I have never experienced in other companies.
cons: It maybe sometimes hard to make teammates understand why it is not easy to treat everyone equally because of their personal learning / development style however it is still manageable when we explain to them and care to spend some extra time.

review_title: Great company to work for, but ability to bear with processes is key
pros: Smart, dedicated, passionate people. Great platform. Collaborative. Steady, growing, secure.
cons: Too many processes. Too political. Too many negative value add pencil pushers. False precision. Tolerance for non-performers. Management don't know how to set an excellent standard for their people and unable to discern the good and bad performer from the pool and make decisive action to preserve the good and remove the bad.  Stringent promotional process that does not make sense. Prey on hardworking people, who do less upward management. Powerpoint culture. Title is important. A lot of churn. A lot of excuses. Too many people who needs constant recognition and reward and forget that they need to do their job well.

job_title: Customer Solutions Agent in Chandler, AZ
pros: The atmosphere is by far the best part of working at PayPal.  The people are really nice and the work place is very modern and comfortable.  Great benefits and incentive to be an efficient worker.
cons: The work itself.  While it is rewarding to turn an irate customer into a happy camper, doing this for eight hours can be mentally taxing.  It makes everyone's goal in the building to work their way up to a position where they're off the phone, making it pretty competitive.

job_title: Member of Technical Staff I in Chennai
pros: Good work life balance,Great learning opportunities, Free snacks and transportation.
cons: Paypal SJ location is good . But in Chennai lot of nepotism. There are some unprofessional managers. Never concentrate on work. Just do time pass  and become pimp for their managers or directors whom they report to. When they recruit they say we want only from IITs . but most of managers does not have even professional degree. These managers spend more time in playing Table tennis than with team or on project. Height of their unheeding attitude is  after coming back from playing Table tennis again sharpen their skills by watching Table tennis videos online.They do not have vision for product as they never worked on product companies ever before.

review_title: Homogeneous team and culture of meh
job_title: Senior Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Good compensation and work life balance. This is why most people work here.
cons: People are hired and promoted by relationships only. Entire leadership teams are of same nationality who speak well but don't have any clue on how to manage engineering teams. Too many metrics and dashboards are fabricated. Code quality is a joke as developers and leaders are all timeline driven without nearly enough interest for investing in developer productivity, tooling, education, and testing. Branching hell adopted to control the poor build and code quality before release.

review_title: Depends on what you want out of it.
job_title: Business Support Specialist in Omaha, NE
pros:
Great Benefits. They now have sick days, 8 weeks paid parental leave, charity days, and other benefits like tuition reimbursement.

Great team of people.
cons:
Very Bureaucratic: takes forever to get things changed and there is no easy way to do so. 

Promotion system is broken: Right now the system is completely broken to high rate of department transfers.

Software: there are always tons of bugs in the system and it causes lots of issues with our customers. So when they call and yell at us all we can say is there is nothing we can do.

review_title: Great company weighed down by politics
pros:
- Great pay and benefits. Probably one of the best among fintech companies.
- If you are looking for work life balance then PayPal is the company to consider. More balance in your life than work.
cons: Company was great a few years ago but has since become extremely bureaucratic. Leadership at the VP and Sr Director level is mediocre at best. Growth is not based on meritocracy. Engineering and product teams are not properly utilized and many teams have no clue what they should be working on as there is constant change in priorities. Movement between teams is impossible and training opportunities are limited. Every year there is a survey conducted to improve employee morale but nothing ever changes. Processes become even more stringent and continue to impact productivity.

pros:
Globally recognised company, good company values and strong value prop in market, the company holds fun social events from time to time. 
Great sabbatical program to loyal employees who can stick around for 5 years.
Discounted gym membership and great health cover with on site massage available, flexible working conditions (but this can be very dependent on your direct manager and which team you are in.)
cons:
Free Wednesday lunch is no more, broken processes with no clear guidance for employees to follow, moving towards more of a corporate banking culture with above average incentive program. (Could do with a revamp)
Lack of support and training has lead to employee turnover and team mates feeling overstretched mentally due to a lot of changes recently.

review_title: Leadership needs to hold itself accountable for results and values
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros: Good pay and benefits.  Exciting products.  Part of eBay, Inc., which lends credibility to the Paypal leadership team.  Workload is manageable in many roles because the company is overstaffed in many spaces.
cons: The leadership team needs to hold itself accountable for results and modeling the eBay Shared Behaviors.  For a company that is as mature as it is and part of eBay, Inc. it is surprising that it is so immature on many levels - lack of clear goal planning structure, weak communications cadences, under utilization of staff and frequent reorgs to solve issues that can be solved without creating employee churn and productivity loss.  Some of the leaders display unprofessional and poor leadership attributes and rather than holding them to the same standard that employees are held to their behavior is condoned because of who they know.

pros: The benefits for insurance are well priced.  They were very liberal with stock options when I first started with the company which has since been reduced.  They are active in the community and host many events.
cons: People are not compensated fairly for the amount of work put in.  Stock options are great but when the stock is not doing well they are completely worthless so annual increases would be a better solution.  The senior management is very poor at making decisions and sticking to them.  There is very little investment in the workforce and most of the money is going to Marketplaces which is even more poorly run than PayPal.

review_title: No College Degree? Don't Work hard?No Problem: Popularity Contest at its Best
pros: Lots of parking, clean gym, easy location to get to
cons: Directors and Managers are highly political. I have seen three AWFs with no college educations get hired one simply due to politics (popularity contest). We had a college educated AWF serve our team for a year and did not get hired on because she worked too hard and did not participate the the B.S. politics. She deserved to get hired on as she put our small team on the map and added tremendous value.

job_title: Software Engineering Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Brand value , market leader is payments , smart folks overall. Consistent growth. Campus in San Jose is nice. Some groups have good amount of fun.
cons: Too many reorgs in product area, ex eBay "leaders" killing the culture of bottom up innovation. Some key tech "gurus" prevent any kind of change in infrastructure.

review_title: Good Work, Pay, and Benefits but Office Politics
job_title: Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
- Good compensation and benefits
- Able to work on interesting and meaningful projects if you take initiative
- Relatively relaxed and laidback
- PTO, work from home, usually not too much work
cons:
- This is said many times before, but quite a bureaucracy with office politics
- Hard to stay on same page as other teams in department
- Knowledge sharing is minimal if you don’t take the time to go out and learn it
- Dependent on product managers you work with,  but often will be brushed aside if your work is considered low priority.
- Many moving parts mean slowness, projects could drag very long if it involves work from other teams

review_title: Great Product, Great Destiny  |  Full of Politics & Bad Process
job_title: Senior Product Manager in San Jose, CA
pros:
Great product, very smart individual contributors. Good benefits, and the company treats it's employees fairly. The company took great pain to make sure in the recent RIF, it took care of leaving employees by giving them a generous severance. Good sabbatical program.

This company can do wonders if under a focused no-nonsense leadership.
cons:
Politics, Politics, Politics, Bad Process, Bad Process, Bad Process. 

What can I say more everyone is trying to screw everyone else in the leadership levels.  It's a technology controlled organization, only worried out getting features out of the door. 

The biggest problem for PayPal is PayPal itself.

review_title: They value outside talent more than existing talent - even if you're an exceeds performer
pros:
- good pay and benefits
- nice desks (ergonomic) and office space
cons:
- politics, politics, politics
- Even when you get hired as an internal candidate for a job at a higher grade level, you don't get moved up. It's always a lateral transfer unless you're one of the "favorites" who actually gets a shot at the very, very few promotion spots that open up annually.
- They prefer to hire from the outside, so get the title you want coming in because getting it through promotion is unlikely despite your performance.
- I thought that being part of a fast-growing company would mean opportunities for advancement. How wrong I was!! It's the opposite of most places I've worked where advancement was much easier.

pros:
Payments is an interesting space to be in
PayPal is still growing. Salaries are decent and hours are reasonable in most roles
Some teams within PayPal are high quality, such as risk management
cons:
For a 'tech' company it is very slow-moving and bureaucratic
CEO has a nice 5 year vision, but there isn't a clear plan of how they will get there
Lots of politics and constant organizational changes which go round in circles
Not many high performers across the business, including at the leadership level
Doesn't feel very meritocratic - career progress more dependent on who shouts the loudest and whether your boss is in favor

job_title: Enhanced Due Diligence Agent in Lavista, NE
pros: The company is up to date with all of the BSA/AML/EDD Standards and train their employees very well when it comes to Risk Assessment Forms and SAR Filings. Great Health, Life Insurance, 401 K (4%) and Flex Time for work life balance.
cons: Unrealistic handle times of 1 hour when cases typically take 2-3 hours or more to review a RISK Assessment Form. It sets the employee up for failure. It is my understanding that they are working on calibrating this issue as it is a common complaint in the department. Also they often switch benchmarks mid half thusly making a bonus increasingly difficult. I still give them a 5 star rating because PayPal is often voted the best place to work in Omaha and I really don't have any other Cons to list and they can be easily remedied.

pros:
* Pay
* 401k matching
* ESPP
* Onsite gym
* Dominate player in the payments space
cons:
* Not very diverse
* If you're not on the "right" ethnicity, you could have a hard time succeeding 
* Not a technology company, MBA run
* To much "fat"
* Lots of unnecessary layers of mgmt
* Even after moving to an agile model, things still move slowly
* "Bad" employees aren't purged, instead, they're just moved to another team

review_title: Money is decent, but mind games abound
job_title: QA Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: An open minded company where you can truly express yourself for who you are, through your work. You can accomplish great things, and if you have a good manager - you'll have opportunities to grow. Your career is what you make it to be. It can be great...
cons: ...and it can be exhausting. Work life balance is mostly terrible. 60 hour workweeks are the norm. Your online from early Dublin hours to late night India hours. It never stops. In the end it's a soul sucking creature that breeds paranoia and leaves you with post traumatic stress disorder.

job_title: Customer Solutions Agent II in Chandler, AZ
pros: I guess theres Good work/life balance.
cons: there is a lot of micromanaging and not having the tools necessary to assist your customers. You are not able to excel into the department you want to move to without meeting or exceeding your goals and that is made very difficult to attain without the right tools to help your customers. The customers you speak with are in control of your career through surveys and you don't have control over what happens or how they rate your surveys no matter how good you are at your job.

pros: Great learning and growing opportunities. Some very fine, talented people. Canteen is subsidised with often a good selection. There is a gym, and game space for blowing of steam or to relax. I do not regret my time here.
cons:
There are a few (actually a bit more than just a few) bad leaders around the Dublin office. When I say bad, I mean really really bad. They should not be near the position they are in. 
Employees are asked periodically to provide feedback to management. Even though the approval rate of a particular supervisor/manager is shockingly low, there is no accountability. They will happily move on doing what they shouldn't be doing. I have seen some shocking examples of leaders make their people physically sick.

review_title: Can be good, can be bad
pros: The benefits are nice, and the work is engaging.  Be glad you're on the PayPal side of the house, and not eBay.
cons:
There's a lot of management here, making the ability to get things done quickly nearly impossible.  Everyone wants their hands in the projects, and projects tend to suffer from "too many cooks".  Far too often good ideas die on the vine, because the many layers of management can't come to an agreement in a timely manner.

The benefits/perks offered to employees in Omaha are far below those offered to workers in San Jose.  Omaha employees are often left feeling like the "unwanted children" at a family reunion.

review_title: It might be different there now...
job_title: Senior Product Marketing Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: When I worked there, I had the privilege to work with some of the most wicked smart people in the valley. Most were very human, humble and eager to teach.
cons: However, by the time I left, most of the wicked-smart/cool/fun people had bailed. Maybe it's changed since Marcus has left...?? Last time I checked though, the marketing teams were still headed up by people that were very much "on-line" focused accountants, that had little vision (or none)?, to support out of box experiential, off-line / retail marketing programs. It's a shame too. We were so close to so many great things, and it just seemed like PayPal marketing higher-ups got in the way of things. Meh.

review_title: It's who you know at PayPal, not what you know
pros:
- Excellent benefits
- Virtually near impossible to get fired unless you make huge mistakes
cons:
- As other reviewers have stated, it's a very political environment.  It's more about who you know rather than how well you do in your job.  I've seen a lot of people who were promoted that didn't really belong in that position because they were buddies with management.  

- Entry level positions are repetitive and get old fast.

job_title: Financial Analyst in San Jose, CA
pros: Very exciting times to work here post-split from eBay, with more opportunities to expand business with other major e-retailers/service vendors  that we could not consider partnerships with before. Product pipeline is strong and service offering/outreach surpasses its competitors, especially for cross-border transactions.
cons:
Very very bureaucratic & slow for what they consider themselves as a "tech" company. A lot of ex-bank/traditional conglomerate executives have on-boarded over the periods, which supposedly add more managerial insight in the decision making process, but also flooded the stakeholder pool and significantly slows down the execution speed with unnecessarily long approval chains and redundant reviews.  
Also very US-centric mindset, upper management has a hard time understanding how business practices in other regions can impact the respective P&L structures, and delegation of decision-making power to regional management is sparse.

review_title: Not as good as it used to be, but could be worse, for a corporate bureaucracy
job_title: Senior Marketing Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Opportunities to work on products impacting lots of people. Many good coworkers.  Good work/life balance, for the most part.  There is a bus from San Francisco to the campus.  Smart people that you will learn a lot from.  Plenty of opportunity for movement within the company, between departments, companies, and countries.  Salaries have become competitive over the last several years.
cons: Politics, great disparity in terms of title/salary progression depending on the department you work in, very slow processes across all departments.  The location is office park central, with nothing around.  As is typical for eBay, salary adjustments are difficult to come by.  The rank and file have very little faith in the senior management of the company (eBay inc.)

review_title: Not a collaborative and fair work culture
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Jose, CA
pros: Growth prospects of company are good - if one is lucky to join the right group chances of moving to senior roles can be descent (promoted once in 2 years).
cons: Not a level playing field - seasoned employees won't share knowledge and information is very poorly documented for the benefit of new comers. Company's forced rating mechanism ensures poor co-operation amongst team members as each tries to ensure his or her position within the company. Very high employee attrition rate, and very frequent re-orgs (at least twice a year) that lead to inefficiency and churn. Quality of data is very poor and no two sources ever match. Performance measurement is very subjective and growth in the company depends on how politically connected one is within the organization.

review_title: Big company with a small company feel and problems
pros: Paypal has an incredible work/life balance.  The salary and benefits are so good that while it's time for me to move on, it's hard to find anything better.  I enjoy the people that I work with and I'm empowered so long as I can execute with my existing resources.
cons: There is very little accountability, until someone breaks something.  Management does not push standards down, leading to every team doing its own thing.  Lots of duplication and disjointed processes, which is frustrating.  Lots of re-orgs, so never really sure who is responsible for what over the long term.  Very limited opportunity for advancement.

review_title: Disgusted and shocked that people act this way, how could a company like PayPal function like this and see revenue.
job_title: User Experience Designer in San Jose, CA
pros: Higher then normal salaries because they need to bribe people to work there. You can leave when you want, nothing holds you back from leaving early, except your 27 meeting a day. You get to do some free traveling on the company dime, and you can expense anything even strippers. You might find some good dudes in the weeds, but that's about it.
cons: You will get no time off, horrible vacation policy. You have to work with a bunch of people that think they are amazing, too many egos. The food sucks its all chemically processed food that comes in plastic bags, even the vegetables. You will sit in 27 meetings a day listening to people argue about features or process because everyone knows everything and nobody can be wrong. It really is a bunch of smart people doing nothing, they love to hear their own voice, its a sad story.

review_title: Passed through bumpy ride of development, ridiculosis, rush environment
job_title: Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
Good software development opportunity.
Ability to lean new technologies.
Frequent team outing and lunches
Able to move to different team within organisation.
Nice pay.
